Literature Review: Nutrient pollution from agricultural sources has become a significant environmental concern in recent decades, with far-reaching implications for ecological health and human well-being. This literature review aims to synthesize current knowledge on the economics of nutrient pollution from agriculture, focusing on trends, impacts, and policy implications.Agricultural intensification has led to increased use of commercial fertilizers and manure, contributing to nutrient pollution in water and air. Ribaudo et al. (2011) reported that nitrogen fertilizer use in the United States increased by 4% between 1996 and 2006, while phosphorus use remained relatively stable. This trend is consistent with global patterns, as highlighted by Lu and Tian (2017), who found a 124% increase in global nitrogen fertilizer use between 1961 and 2013.The spatial correlation between agricultural intensification and nutrient concentrations in waterbodies has been well-documented. Sobota et al. (2013) demonstrated that agricultural activities account for approximately 37% of nitrogen inputs to U.S. surface waters. Similarly, Sharpley et al. (2013) found that agriculture is responsible for up to 80% of phosphorus loads in some watersheds.The environmental impacts of nutrient pollution are diverse and significant. Eutrophication, caused by excess nutrients in water bodies, leads to algal blooms, hypoxia, and fish kills. Diaz and Rosenberg (2008) reported that the number of coastal dead zones worldwide has doubled every decade since the 1960s, largely due to nutrient pollution. In the United States, the Gulf of Mexico hypoxic zone, primarily attributed to agricultural runoff, covered an area of 6,952 square miles in 2019 (NOAA, 2019).While the biophysical impacts of nutrient pollution are well-understood, economic research on the associated damages remains incomplete. Dodds et al. (2009) estimated that eutrophication in U.S. freshwaters results in annual losses of $2.2 billion, primarily through decreased property values and recreational opportunities. However, this estimate likely underrepresents the full economic impact, as it does not account for all ecosystem services affected by nutrient pollution.The health impacts of nutrient pollution, particularly through contaminated drinking water, represent a critical yet understudied area. Ward et al. (2018) found that nitrate contamination in U.S. drinking water could be responsible for up to 12,594 cases of cancer annually. However, comprehensive national estimates of health-related costs due to nutrient pollution are lacking.Policy design for addressing nutrient pollution faces challenges due to its nonpoint source nature. Shortle and Horan (2017) reviewed various policy instruments, including input taxes, ambient taxes, and tradable permits, concluding that a mix of policy approaches is often necessary for cost-effective pollution reduction. Ribaudo et al. (2014) estimated that a nitrogen credit trading program in the Chesapeake Bay watershed could reduce nitrogen loadings by 25% at half the cost of command-and-control regulations.Despite these insights, significant knowledge gaps remain in understanding the full economic implications of nutrient pollution. Keiser et al. (2019) highlighted the need for more comprehensive benefit-cost analyses of water quality regulations, noting that existing studies often fail to capture the full range of benefits associated with improved water quality.The air quality impacts of nutrient pollution, particularly ammonia emissions from livestock operations, represent another understudied area. Paulot and Jacob (2014) estimated that ammonia emissions from agriculture contribute to 3.3 million premature deaths globally each year, but economic valuations of these impacts at national scales are limited.Future research directions should focus on developing more holistic estimates of the externalities associated with nutrient pollution. This includes improving our understanding of the long-term impacts on ecosystem services, quantifying health-related costs from contaminated drinking water sources, and assessing the economic implications of air quality degradation due to agricultural emissions.In conclusion, while significant progress has been made in understanding the biophysical aspects of nutrient pollution from agriculture, economic research lags behind in fully characterizing the associated damages and identifying cost-effective policy solutions. Addressing these knowledge gaps is crucial for informing evidence-based policies that can effectively mitigate the environmental and economic impacts of nutrient pollution while supporting sustainable agricultural practices.
